tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to the people of all nations. AT: "the people of all nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He sits enthroned above the cherubim
tn.text: The psalmist speaks as if the throne on which Yahweh sits is above the cherubim on the lid of the ark of the covenant decrees in the temple.

tn.ref: Yahweh is great in Zion; he is exalted above all the nations
tn.text: "Not only is Yahweh great in Zion, he is exalted above all the nations" or "Not only does Yahweh rule in Zion, he rules over all the nations"

tn.ref: he is exalted above all the nations
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people in all the nations exalt him" or "people in all nations praise him greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let them praise your great and awesome name
tn.text: Here the author shifts from speaking about God, to speaking to God. After this phrase though, he shifts back to speaking about God.
The abstract noun "justice" can be translated using the phrase "what is just." AT: "he loves doing what is just" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

The abstract noun "fairness" is a metonym for the laws that are fair. "The laws you have established are fair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
